label: 290. Madame Baptiste to Bp Patrick Lynch -- July 31, 1863
description: Letter from Madame Baptiste to Bishop Patrick Lynch with news from the Ursuline Convent and Academy.  Madame Baptiste writes about purchasing provisions and asks the Bishop for advice on investing the "thousands of Confederate money" she expects as the pupils arrive for the new school year. July 31, 1863. 4p.

metadata.value: Letter from Madame Baptiste to Bishop Patrick Lynch with news from the Ursuline Convent and Academy.  Madame Baptiste writes about purchasing provisions and asks the Bishop for advice on investing the "thousands of Confederate money" she expects as the pupils arrive for the new school year. metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: A.M.D.G. Ursuline Convent Columbia, S.C. July 31st 1863 My dearest Brother, Both John & I have been wondering at your silence -- he feels a little hurt at your not noticing his letters, & so neglecting him I believe. Today he tells me of anther hogshead of sugar being at the depot for us, & we are so much obliged to you for it. Mr Dempsey of Macon Georgia who has just left, offers to purchase sugar for us there too, at a cheaper rate than it sells here, & John advises ne to get some as a safe investment. We also want coffee & rice -- but if you don't send the bills along with the Merchandise, I'll not be satisfied. Please write soon, & tell us how you are & if you will visit us before or after our retreat. You know we enter into it on the feast of the "Transfiguration" & remain until the "Assumption." Father Gache will I expect leave Lynchburg on tomorrow, as his furlough extends from[End Page 1] Aug 1st to the 20th. I asked you in my last letter about our going out to see Barhamville with John, but I am afraid retreat time will come before I get your reply. We have almost concluded to buy it, & are anxious to do so -- the interest of our academy & the health of our Sisters both seem to require a country place & fresh air. Pupils are already coming in, & soon we shall have thousands of confederate money on hand, besides what we already have in Bank & invested in Cotton. We purpose also selling our cotton rather than pay the present taxes, storage, & insurance on it, & turning that, in to Barhamville property also. Please let me hear from you at your earliest convenience. What about this will & letter of yours -- sent from[End Page 2] Camden. Shall I send it to you -- I would have done so before, but was expecting you up. I believe I'll enclose you the letters & keep the will, as it is a larger package & Charleston is so unsafe too. But I will send it immediately if you wish. Genl Beauregard's sister called her a few days since -- Mrs Proctor, I think is her name, we had quite a pleasant conversation & she spoke of placing her little daughter with us. We have just recd a young lady of some pretensions from New Orleans Mademoiselle Le Sveum? -- a good Catholic. Please excuse the great haste in which I write. John returns from Cheraw on Wednesday. Mother was well & busy -- Father looking very well indeed. Francis well excepting his shoulder -- singular coincidence was it not, he & John getting such a severe fall by their horses on the same day?[End Page 3] Sister Gertrude, I am sorry to say, is growing every day more like poor Bernard & is growing more inert -- every thing fatigues her. Sr Rose too looks very much like a consumptive. Sr Marie St Angel in confined to her bed the greater part of her time, & today we have three sick Lay Sisters the last however I do not mind, it is only the warm weather & some disarrangement of systems. You must not go the trouble of looking after coffee & rice for us now, because I mentioned them, for I intend asking Mr Huchet to get us the rice as he did before, & will write to Mr Dempsey of Macon, accept his kind offer, & get it cheaper than here, where it sells at $4. pr lb. I will say nothing of the sign of the times, for I have not space. All join in grateful respects to you begging your prayers & benediction especially Sr Gertrude & your own Sister Ellen Sr Baptiste Sup.[End Page 4]
